newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - Evening Standard - June 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Evening Standard - June 4.

text.p: This daily press summary is produced for Reuters by the Broadcast Monitoring Company, which is responsible for its contents.
A KILLING EVEN AS YARD WARN

A man was shot dead in Brixton last night, only a few hundred yards away from where Chief Inspector Alan O'Gorman was addressing a public meeting and calling for more co-operation between the police and local community to stop the culture of guns, drugs and violence from increasing.
EU MOVES TO DEFEND FOREIGN INVESTMENT

The European Commission is to take action to stop EU member states discriminating against foreign investors taking part in domestic privatisations. A "general good provision" exists to limit foreign investment where defence, security, health or public order reasons apply, but it has been abused for protectionist reasons. The Commission hopes that a more precise definition of when the general good provision can be applied will deter infringements.
D-MARK SUFFERS AS EMU WORRIES PERSIST

The markets are still being affected by fears that Germany's fudging on the criteria of entry for Emu will allow weak currencies to join the Euro, with dealers continuing to sell the Deutschmark on the money markets.
BRITAIN SETS PACE ON THE M&A TRAIL

A survey published today by Price Waterhouse finds that British companies are the most aggressive acquirers in Europe, with only Dutch companies coming close in terms of European mergers and acquisitions.

RUSSIA SET FOR OK ON $1.7BN DOLLAR LOANS PACKAGE A package of loans for Russia worth $1.7bn (1bn stg) is expected to be approved by the World Bank this month, in an attempt to provide financial help to the country in its efforts to cope the social consequnces of economic reforms.
